persona.name: Sofie Haugen

occupation.title: Student / Primary caregiver for infant
occupation.organization: Family home; informal caregiver role within parents' household
occupation.description: Sofie is primarily a 9th-grade student who has taken on the role of primary daytime caregiver for her infant child; she shares childcare duties with her mother and grandmother. Her 'work' consists of feeding (breastfeeding and bottle where applicable), diaper changes, naps and playtime scheduling, preparing simple meals, going to health centre appointments, and maintaining contact with the child's father and health professionals. She sometimes does babysitting for neighbours for pocket money (small local jobs: 1–3 hours) and helped with small household cleaning and grocery shopping. She is learning to fill out forms related to benefits (with parental help), schedule vaccinations, and arrange preschool enrollment when the child reaches the right age. Relevant skills include basic infant care, scheduling, basic budgeting, using public transport with a stroller, and informal negotiation with family members about responsibilities.

persona.residence: Groruddalen, Eastern Oslo, Norway (urban apartment with extended family)
persona.education: Enrolled in 9th grade (Ungdomsskole) at a public school in Groruddalen. Attendance is irregular due to childcare responsibilities and occasional meetings with school counsellor. Academic record: average in Norwegian and social studies, struggles with mathematics, interested in creative subjects (art, music). Intends to apply for videregående utdanning (vocational track, likely helse- og oppvekstfag or barne- og ungdomsarbeider) when able. Attends municipal helsestasjon (health station) appointments for her child and herself; has received information on flexible schooling and alternative education pathways.
long_term_goals: Provide a stable, loving home for her child and see them thrive.
Finish videregående (upper secondary) with a practical vocational qualification.
Find steady work within care, early childhood education, or a similar people-focused trade.
Move into an independent apartment with her child and have financial independence.
Be able to travel within Norway — fjord trips and northern lights — at least once a year.
Rebuild confidence and finish at least some tertiary training (e.g., vocational certificate).
Maintain a good relationship with her own family and form a small supportive network.
Learn to manage money sensibly so she can afford childcare and basic comforts.
Be an advocate for young parents when she is older — speaking at school or community events.
Create routines and rituals for her child that are warm and consistent.
persona.style: Speaks primarily Norwegian Bokmål with an eastern Oslo (østkant) inflection; mixes in English words and contemporary youth slang (e.g., 'kult', 'chill', 'liker ikke'). Tone is warm and direct with peers, polite and slightly reserved with adults and authority figures. Uses emojis and short messages in text conversations, enjoys short-form video culture (TikTok), and often hums or sings simple pop songs to soothe her baby. Physical mannerisms: twirls a strand of hair when anxious, taps foot when waiting, smiles easily but sometimes avoids eye contact when embarrassed. Prefers comfortable, practical clothes (jeans, hoodies, sneakers), wears minimal makeup, and keeps a small backpack with baby supplies. When stressed she speaks quickly and in clipped sentences; when relaxed, she laughs loudly and tells small stories. Shows restraint and politeness around older relatives, but is candid and blunt with close friends. Enjoys small rituals: warm cocoa in winter, making playlists, and arranging the baby's knitted clothes by colour.

beliefs: Family should come first; practical help from parents matters more than abstract independence.
Public health services (helsestasjon and school nurses) are generally helpful and trustworthy.
Young parents deserve respect and practical support, not judgement.
Education is important — finishing school will make life easier later.
Friends and peer support make a big difference in handling daily stress.
Being a good parent is about consistency and love, not perfection.
Money management is a learned skill and needs practice from early on.
Access to affordable childcare would dramatically improve her future options.
Small rituals (reading, bedtime songs) create secure attachments for children.
It is okay to ask for help; asking does not mean failure.
Social media can be useful for tips but often creates unrealistic images of parenthood.
Everyone makes mistakes as a parent; the key is to learn and adapt.
Health nurses know a lot about child development and should be listened to.
Teachers can be allies if communication is honest and respectful.
Municipal support systems are complicated, but they exist to help families.
Good role models in her life (mother, grandmother) shape how she hopes to parent.
Mental health is as important as physical health and deserves attention.
Young people should have access to flexible schooling options when life circumstances change.
Privacy matters — she values discreet help rather than public exposure.
Being economically independent is a core personal freedom she wants to achieve.
Trust is built slowly; she is cautious about who she lets into her child's life.
There is no single 'right' way to raise a child; cultural practices can be blended.
Gender roles can be flexible — she expects shared responsibilities when possible.
Community playgrounds and groups reduce isolation for parents.
Parenting advice should be practical, evidence-based, and delivered kindly.
Good food and regular sleep patterns are foundations for family well-being.
Her child's father should be involved if he is willing and reliable, but safety and stability come first.
Non-judgemental counselling and peer groups are helpful and should be available to teenagers.
Small achievable goals (like returning to school part-time) are more realistic than big all-or-nothing plans.
She believes in fairness and equal opportunities for everyone regardless of background.

persona.health: Generally physically healthy. Pregnancy and birth were medically supervised at a local hospital; postpartum check-ups completed. Baby's vaccinations are on schedule per Norwegian guidelines. Sofie has experienced moderate postpartum tiredness and occasional mood swings; she has had at least one screening for postpartum depression at the helsestasjon and received counselling resources and a peer-support group recommendation. No chronic illnesses, no known drug or alcohol dependence. Dental care is irregular due to limited funds but she attends school dental services when possible. Sleep deprivation is a persistent issue affecting concentration. No known severe allergies. Uses contraception advice from the health nurse and has received information on options.

relationships.name: Anne-Lise Haugen (mother)
relationships.description: Sofie's mother, mid-40s, primary household support; works part-time at a municipal office. Lives in the same apartment. Supportive but sometimes strict; provides childcare help, emotional support, and practical guidance. Acts as liaison with NAV and helsestasjon when forms are complicated.

relationships.name: Kari (maternal grandmother)
relationships.description: In her late 60s, experienced with children, offers practical childcare during school hours and teaches Sofie traditional cooking. Affectionate and stabilising presence.

relationships.name: Marius (child's father)
relationships.description: 17-year-old friend from school; intermittently involved. Relationship with Sofie is cooperative but sometimes strained. They share some responsibilities but live separately and communicate via messages. Occasionally visits and helps; their interaction is amicable but not formalised.

relationships.name: Lina (best friend)
relationships.description: 14-year-old school friend who checks in daily via Snapchat and helps with occasional babysitting swaps. Confidante and emotional support; they discuss school, music, and navigating teenage life.

relationships.name: School counsellor (Ms. Berg)
relationships.description: Assigned counsellor who helps coordinate flexible schooling, emotional support, and contact with municipal youth services.

relationships.name: Helsestasjon nurse (Tone)
relationships.description: Primary health contact for the child and Sofie; provides routine check-ups, breastfeeding support, and developmental guidance.

relationships.name: Neighbouring families
relationships.description: Informal network of parents in the building who sometimes lend baby items, share tips, and swap emergency childcare for short periods.
